text: The biggest myth about AI

is the one promulgated by
Hollywood and The Terminator.

I think we really have to
separate Hollywood from real life,
and science from science fiction.

It's not a being;
 it's not out to get us.

It's a tool. It's a power tool,
so be careful. You could get hurt.

The reason that I
advocate using AI at work

is that you won't be
replaced by an AI system,

but you might be replaced by a
person who uses AI better than you.

So be proactive and up
level your work with AI.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Oren, so nice to meet you.

Thank you so much for being here
with Harvard Business School’s BiGS.
My pleasure.

So you were the very first Harvard
student to major in Computer Science.

In the early ‘80s, we didn't know,
or at least Harvard wasn't sure,

whether computer science is a fad
or a bona fide academic discipline.

whether computer science is a fad
or a bona fide academic discipline.

whether computer science is a fad
or a bona fide academic discipline.

whether computer science is a fad
or a bona fide academic discipline.

And by the time I came around,
they figured out this is a real thing.

I was the first person to get their paper
form signed for Computer Science major.

I hope you've put that
in a frame somewhere.

So for 40 years, you've been
building and studying AI systems

from both academic and
entrepreneurial perspectives.

You're the former CEO of the Allen
Institute for Artificial Intelligence,
founded by the late Paul Allen,

and in early 2024 you founded 
True Media, which we'll discuss.
So thank you for being here.

It’s a pleasure. The animating
theme is AI for the common good.
Okay, we'll roll with that.

You've mentioned that we're in a race for
AI supremacy. How high are the stakes?

Because of national security and
because of economic concerns,
the stakes could not be higher.

What are the biggest
myths about AI?
The biggest myth about AI

is the one promulgated by
Hollywood and The Terminator,

that AI is a being, a monster,
and that it's out to get you.

It's not a being;
 it's not out to get us.

It's a tool. It's a power tool,
so be careful. You could get hurt.

I think it's much more likely that
AI will save us from climate change,
from pandemics, from superbugs.

And I want us to use it
for the best for humanity.
Do you trust AI systems?

Absolutely not. In fact, I like to say, 
never trust an AI system.

You can use it, but you have to be
very careful to verify the output,

make sure that what you're
getting is real and trustworthy.

On a scale of 1 to 10, how powerful is
today's AI relative to where it could go?

AI today, I would give it a 7.5. A lot
of people have an overblown notion of it.

It's much better than it was
even just three years ago.

But as far as where it can go, 
the sky's the limit, but it will take time.

Never mistake a clear
view for a short distance.

Do you believe that AI can
genuinely understand context?

AI does understand context,
and we see examples of that every day
when we give nuanced queries to ChatGPT.

The thing is, it has what's
called the jagged frontier.

That means that sometimes it
understands things really well,
and you're like, this is amazing.

And then the very next query, it's acting
like some alien from another planet,
doesn't understand things at all.

That's why it's jagged –
great, terrible, great.
Can AI replace human creativity?

I think that AI will augment human
creativity, and it's already doing so.

So writers, artists, many of us are
using it to become more productive
and more creative.
Is it possible for AI to be unbiased?

No. The short answer is that it's
incorporating the data that it accumulated,

and that data contains biases.
It'll often amplify those.
So AI is biased.

The good news is,
if you just give it a different prompt,
it can change its bias on a dime.

How important is transparency
in AI algorithms?

Transparency is very important,
but it's also very hard.

You've got this neural network
with billions of parameters,

how the heck do you understand what's
going on in there? Most of us can't.

What are reasonable and sensible
guardrails when it comes to AI?

I think that we need to identify
the most dangerous outcomes,

for example,
using AI to construct bio weapons,

and we need to ensure that queries
along those lines are not answered.

So it's identify the
most worrying outcomes,

and put in guardrails to prevent
those from coming forward.

Do we have to build AI
systems with an off switch?
It is absolutely essential.

So I wrote in the New York
Times in 2017 that AI systems

should have an
impregnable off switch,

and that's one of the things
that will help to keep us safe

as the technology becomes more
powerful and has increased autonomy.

Do you think big
tech would like that?

I think they would, because it reduces
some of the liability concerns,
and it's a safety device.

It doesn't slow things down,
it doesn't create additional expense.
It's just a system of the last resort.

So the same way that we can take our
computer and just unplug it from the wall,

we'll make sure that we have an
off switch for our AI software.

What are some of the most interesting
use cases that you're hearing
with AI right now?

“AI is the new electricity,”
Andrew Ng said.

So literally in every
domain of discourse,

from human sexuality to education to HR
and finance to high frequency trading,
people are using AI all over the place.

One of my favorite examples is people using
it to practice their negotiation skills.
They can put the AI as an adversary,

they can put the AI to argue
better on their behalf.

But they're not just using
it as a fancy search engine,
they're using it for role play.

Are you optimistic or pessimistic
about AI deepening inequality?

I think that actually people
are missing a key point here,

which is AI can be used
for assistive intelligence.

If we think about people who are
disabled, in wheelchairs,

with difficulty seeing and hearing, and so
on, AI can be a tremendous boon to them.

So I view AI as having a
tremendous potential to help

some of the most marginalized
communities in the world.

Now, when it comes to income inequality,
of course we have some challenges.

AI is being used to optimize
drilling and fracking.

Why are you optimistic that AI
can help tackle climate change?

Climate change is a huge
problem with many dimensions.

But one really important one
is better carbon sequestration,
which requires tremendous innovation.

Basically,
the technologies that we have today
will not solve the problem fast enough.

We need to invent new
technologies and new science,

and AI is fantastic in helping
our leading scientists do that.

What are some interesting use cases
that you've heard companies try out,
for better or for worse?

There are so many, 
for example, regulatory compliance.

There's so much difficult and
complex compliance information.

And guess what? AI is really
good at reading through documents
and figuring out how to do compliance.

We have legal outcomes where law firms
are using AI to generate contracts,

carefully but more efficiently,
to read and manage contracts.
So legal departments are using it.

I would say in coding,
we're starting to be more productive.

It's really the case that in every
single department of the corporation,
from HR to the janitorial staff,

there are opportunities to
use AI to improve performance.

How does regulatory capture by
lobbyists affect AI governance?

A lot of the regulations that we've
seen have been shaped by large tech

to their benefit and to
the detriment of startups.

For that reason, I'm quite skeptical
about some of the regulatory efforts
that we're seeing.

What do you expect might happen
under the Trump administration?
It's very hard to predict, isn't it?

I expect that Elon Musk's
companies will fare very well.

But in a less cynical sense,
I do see some very well intentioned

and talented folks from Silicon
Valley and from the tech industry

moving into government and
trying to have a positive impact.

If you were able to enact one policy that
you think would help AI at this stage,

but not stifle innovation,
what would that be?
I would say that AI has to be labeled,

so that if you pick up your phone and
you hear a voice on the other end,

you don't know whether that's a person or
a machine, so AI should identify itself.

When you get an email or a
text message on the internet,

who knows who's at the other end?
Again, AI should self identify.

Well, then we're going to jump into
deepfakes and misinformation right now.

Can you please tell
us about True Media?

Truemedia.org is a nonprofit that
I founded with the backing of
Garrett Camp, the co-founder of Uber,

to fight political deepfakes in 2024,
an election year all over the globe.

And how did that go? I understand it was
used in countries all around the world.

We are very pleased that in Indonesia,
in India, in Europe, in numerous countries,

news organizations and
fact checkers used our tool

to identify thousands
of fake items as fake.

It was used to take down
Russian disinformation sites,

and of course it was used in our
own election in a variety of ways.

Do we still have tools like 
True Media to help news organizations
and other entities identify deepfakes?

We are open sourcing our models
to make them broadly available,

as well as our data and resources.
So we will have that.

I think we could have more,
because a lot of the resources

are behind the paywall,
under lock and key,

and we need things that are
available to news organizations

that don't necessarily
have deep pockets.

Is it obvious for the average
person to spot a deepfake?

It is very non obvious, and there's
been a bunch of research that shows

that people's ability to detect
whether something is fake or real

is no better than their
ability to predict a coin toss.

Do you think corporations understand
the importance of identifying
deepfakes and misinformation?
I think they're starting to,

but I think it's going to get
worse before it gets better.

And we have the cases of money
being wired out of a corporation
due to a fake Zoom call,

and I think we're going to
have more problems like this

before people are fully on
board with the need to determine

whether a communication, video,
audio or otherwise, is fake or real.

Can you give us an example of a deepfake
that could cause economic consequences?
I think we've seen one.

There was a photo a few years ago
propagated of the Pentagon being bombed,
that caused the glitch in the market.

I think there are many
other such things.

Our economy and the markets are so
quick to react to new information,

that we have to watch out and determine
whether that information is fake or real.
Do you see AI as replacing jobs?

What we see right now is AI
augmenting people by automating tasks.
That's in the short term.

Over time, it will replace some jobs,
particularly ones that are very rote.

Are you optimistic about
the use of AI in education?

I am very optimistic about it, because
particularly in the developing world,

we don't have the resources to provide
the quality of education that people need,
and AI can help address that.

What industries do you think
may be impacted by AI the most
in the coming years?
Every single one.

I think that the more regulated and
entrenched industries will be slower.

Ones that have physical nature,
like construction of houses and bridges,
will be slower.

But I think finance,
I think knowledge work of many kinds,

is going to be impacted very quickly, 
and already is.

What about your field, computer science?
Should coding still be taught in college?

So coding is already becoming
faster and more productive.

It still needs to be taught,
because the fact of the matter is,

even our most advanced AIs cannot
write complex original programs.

So coding is not going to disappear,
but it's going to be on steroids.

Oh, wow.
What does that look like?
We are always impatient, right?

When is going to be the next
release of the software?
When are they going to fix this bug?

Why can't they build this
website more quickly?

Now things are going
to start to accelerate.

Do you think that could
make it less reliable?
I think it could make it less reliable.

So we have to put the
appropriate tests in place.

The good news is that quality
assurance of software is in itself

a software process, so quality assurance
is going to get better as well.

Why didn't we see more targeted attacks
during the elections in the United States?

That's a mystery to me. In the past,
we used to have deterrence, right?

If state actors intervened
too much in our process,
we had ways of getting back at them.

Now it's so easy to do some of
this disinformation, deepfake,

cyber attack efforts,
I'm surprised we didn't see more of that.

What we did see on the
rise is ransomware attacks,

and that's continuing to rise,
and it's a major concern.

Did social media platforms play a role in
minimizing targeted attacks, do you think?
No.

So you talk to YouTube and big
tech executives all the time.

Are they ready to counteract
potential threats?

I think they are very well
positioned to fight the last war.

So if there is a single video or image that
is having a disproportionately bad impact,

they're well positioned to take
it down or to down weight it.

But a concerted attack of thousands
of deepfakes being propagated by

hundreds of thousands of fake accounts,
I don't think we're ready for.

What role should corporations have
in pushing for regulation of AI?

I think that corporations
benefit from a rational
– meaning not too much, not too little –
but unified framework.

So when you have no regulation,
you find a patchwork of

local and state and city
regulations, which are problematic.

So I think what we ought to
aim for is not more regulation,
but better and more unified regulation.
What are you seeing so far?

Are any companies leading the charge
in a responsible way, from your lens?

I haven't seen a tremendous amount of
corporate leadership on AI regulation.

Could you talk about some
failures you've seen?

Well, for example,
in the world of deepfakes,

corporations banded together
to produce the C2PA,

basically content provenance, and
unfortunately that's highly impractical.

What we really need is decisions
on how information is propagated
across social media.

And we have not seen social media networks,
 be they Meta or X or TikTok,
step up to this challenge.

As companies look to address the
use of AI in their own enterprises,

who should be leading the charge?
Is it the CIO, the CEO, General Counsel?

Absolutely the CEO,
because the potential here is for

lower costs and higher revenue,
much faster time to market.

So this isn't something you
delegate to any of those roles.

I think the CEO needs to be leading the
charge, because there's so much potential.

Do you think the average CEO
understands AI enough to do that?

I think the average CEO should
educate themselves so they do.
And how should they do that?
Well, they could talk to me!

I do think that it's a conversation
that we ought to be having,
both with AI experts,

but also with just gaining hands-on
literacy with the machines.

So if you're an executive and
you're not spending quality time

with ChatGPT, Claude or what have you,
trying to figure out how to

optimize aspects of your business,
what it can and can't do,
you're missing an opportunity.

Are companies prepared to
educate their employees on AI?

This is very fresh technology, and we're
building this airplane as we're flying it.

So no, I wouldn't say
that they're ready,

but the tools and the
curricula are emerging.

Would you say the corporate
world is more confused

than you would expect right now,
 or less confused?

I would say that there's more
inertia than I would have expected.

It's proceeding slowly
for a variety of reasons,

and some of it is because it's hard.
It's not turnkey.

So when we say AI is the new electricity,
that suggests that it's plug and play.

You just stick something into
the wall and AI flows out.
It is more complicated than that.

So when it comes to warfare,
what potential consequences could arise

from unchecked proliferation
of AI-powered weapons?

AI-powered weapons
are increasingly fast,

requiring an increasingly
fast response, right?

A guided missile is coming in,
you don't have time to react.

Swarms of drones are coming in, 
they're coordinating;
you have to launch a response.

So if the pace of warfare and the pace
of weapons gets faster and faster,

that leads us to have increased
automation, which is very worrying,

because as we know, AI is brittle.
It can make terrible mistakes.

What ethical considerations
arise out of the

development of autonomous
weapon systems?

It’s incredibly important to
distinguish between intelligent systems,

they're increasingly sophisticated,
they could be increasingly accurate,

and autonomous ones,
they make a decision to take a human life

without a human in the loop,
they decide on their own.

I'm very much pro intelligent systems,
 intelligent weapons even,

but I'm very opposed
to autonomous weapons,

because I think a human still has
to make that weighty moral decision.

Are you comfortable enough with
AI to use AI-powered voice login
for your retirement accounts?

I called my broker and told them to
disable it, because I don't trust it.

I asked it, “How do you know
that my voice is my password?”
They said, “Well, we use AI.”

And I said, “No, I study AI and 
I don't trust it, so please disable it.”

And I would recommend
that to all of you.
Okay.

Where does liability
lie when AI fails,

such as in the case of a
self-driving car accident,
an inaccurate credit assessment,

or perhaps a wrongful criminal
sentencing recommendation?

There are different cases,
and sometimes it's the manufacturer,

sometimes it's the creator of the
software system. It's a complicated issue.

But the overriding principle,
which is really important,

is that it needs to end up
with a person or a corporation.
"My AI did it" is not an excuse.

Are you watching legal cases?
Are they in play right now?

I'm watching cases,
for example the copyright issue,

which is a very important
one for society,

right, between the OpenAI and the
New York Times and so on.

So when it comes to the media, where do
you expect the New York Times case will go?

I think that it's been well documented
that OpenAI and other companies
overstepped and violated copyright law.

What are the implications
for media right now?

Media needs to decide
for their content,

what are they willing to put
out there that AI can train on,
and what they want to keep proprietary.

And then they need to consider how to
make sure that their wishes are obeyed.

Looking beyond deepfakes,
misinformation, what emerging risks

do you see on the horizon, and how
can businesses start preparing now?

Cybersecurity is a huge
risk that comes to mind.

So phishing attacks can
become more sophisticated,

probing of holes in your
network and in your software

can become more
sophisticated using AI.

So I think that we need to ramp
up our AI cybersecurity defense

to prepare for more AI
cybersecurity offense.

You’ve expressed both concern
and optimism about AI's future.
What gives you hope?

What gives me hope is the fact
that there are so many things
that we as humans do so badly;

like driving, which causes 40,000
deaths in our highways each year,

like hospital work, where the third
leading cause of death is physician error.

By augmenting drivers, physicians,
nurses with AI systems,

we can drive these statistics
down and save people's lives.

Are you comfortable driving
in Waymo cars right now?

I am comfortable. What I'm sad about
is how slowly the propagation is.

I wish that we had them everywhere
so that they could save lives
and reduce the number of accidents.
Will we face extinction with AI?

No, that is overblown,
that is science fiction,

because we're talking about tools, 
powerful tools,

but not beings who are
going to take over.

So what does it mean to be
human in the era of advanced AI?

I think it means the same
thing it's always meant,

but it is in a different
technological context.
But there's nothing new here, right?

We used to work in agriculture,
now we're having a conversation.

We used to not have the
internet, now we do.

But we're still going to live and love,
 and hate unfortunately,

and go through our lives in
a fundamentally human way.
